intro: Enchylaena paradoxa, commonly known as the paradoxical acanthus, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Acanthaceae and is characterized by its striking, spiny leaves and showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub, reaching heights of up to 2 meters, with opposite, ovate leaves that have prominent veins. Its flowers, which are usually pink or purple, are arranged in whorls along the stems, making it an ornamental plant in some regions. Enchylaena paradoxa is adapted to arid environments and thrives in full sun with well-drained soil.
